messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Maximum 𝑘- vs. ℓ-colourings of graphsThis work was supported by UKRI EP/X024431/1 and by a Clarendon Fund Scholarship. For the purpose of Open Access, the authors have applied a CC BY public copyright licence to any Author Accepted Manuscript version arising from this submission. All data is provided in full in the results section of this paper.

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present polynomial-time SDP-based algorithms for the following problem: For fixed k≤ℓ𝑘ℓk\leq\ell, given a real number ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and a graph G𝐺G that admits a k𝑘k-colouring with a ρ𝜌\rho-fraction of the edges coloured properly, it returns an ℓℓ\ell-colouring of G𝐺G with an (α​ρ−ε)𝛼𝜌𝜀(\alpha\rho-\varepsilon)-fraction of the edges coloured properly in polynomial time in G𝐺G and 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon. Our algorithms are based on the algorithms of Frieze and Jerrum [Algorithmica’97] and of Karger, Motwani and Sudan [JACM’98]. For k=2,ℓ=3formulae-sequence𝑘2ℓ3k=2,\ell=3, our algorithm achieves an approximation ratio α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, which is the best possible. When k𝑘k is fixed and ℓℓ\ell grows large, our algorithm achieves an approximation ratio of α=1−o​(1/ℓ)𝛼1𝑜1ℓ\alpha=1-o(1/\ell). When k,ℓ𝑘ℓk,\ell are both large, our algorithm achieves an approximation ratio of α=1−1/ℓ+2​ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ−o​(ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ)−O​(1/k2)𝛼11ℓ2ℓ𝑘ℓ𝑜ℓ𝑘ℓ𝑂1superscript𝑘2\alpha=1-1/\ell+2\ln\ell/k\ell-o(\ln\ell/k\ell)-O(1/k^{2}); if we fix d=ℓ−k𝑑ℓ𝑘d=\ell-k and allow k,ℓ𝑘ℓk,\ell to grow large, this is α=1−1/ℓ+2​ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ−o​(ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ)𝛼11ℓ2ℓ𝑘ℓ𝑜ℓ𝑘ℓ\alpha=1-1/\ell+2\ln\ell/k\ell-o(\ln\ell/k\ell). By extending the results of Khot, Kindler, Mossel and O’Donnell [SICOMP’07] to the promise setting, we show that for large k𝑘k and ℓℓ\ell, assuming Khot’s Unique Games Conjecture (UGC), it is \NP-hard to achieve an approximation ratio α𝛼\alpha greater than 1−1/ℓ+2​ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ+o​(ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ)11ℓ2ℓ𝑘ℓ𝑜ℓ𝑘ℓ1-1/\ell+2\ln\ell/k\ell+o(\ln\ell/k\ell), provided that ℓℓ\ell is bounded by a function that is o​(exp⁡(k3))𝑜3𝑘o(\exp(\sqrt[3]{k})). For the case where d=ℓ−k𝑑ℓ𝑘d=\ell-k is fixed, this bound matches the performance of our algorithm up to o​(ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ)𝑜ℓ𝑘ℓo(\ln\ell/k\ell). Furthermore, by extending the results of Guruswami and Sinop [ToC’13] to the promise setting, we prove that it is \NP-hard to achieve an approximation ratio greater than 1−1/ℓ+8​ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ+o​(ln⁡ℓ/k​ℓ)11ℓ8ℓ𝑘ℓ𝑜ℓ𝑘ℓ1-1/\ell+8\ln\ell/k\ell+o(\ln\ell/k\ell), provided again that ℓℓ\ell is bounded as before (but this time without assuming the UGC).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Estimating orthant probabilities of high-dimensional gaussian vectors with an application to set estimation",
        "(2+ε𝜀\\varepsilon)-Sat is NP-hard",
        "New np-hardness results for 3-coloring and 2-to-1 label cover",
        "Algebraic approach to promise constraint satisfaction",
        "An algorithmic blend of LPs and ring equations for promise CSPs",
        "Promise Constraint Satisfaction: Algebraic Structure and a Symmetric Boolean Dichotomy",
        "SDPs and Robust Satisfiability of Promise CSP",
        "Derandomization of dimensionality reduction and SDP based algorithms",
        "Robustly solvable constraint satisfaction problems",
        "An Invariance Principle for the Multi-slice, with Applications",
        "On rich 2-to-1 games",
        "On Approximability of Satisfiable k𝑘k-CSPs: I",
        "On Approximability of Satisfiable k𝑘k-CSPs: II",
        "On Approximability of Satisfiable k𝑘k-CSPs: III",
        "The clipping loss in correlation detectors for arbitrary input signal-to-noise ratios",
        "The orthant probabilities of four gaussian variates",
        "Near-optimal algorithms for maximum constraint satisfaction problems",
        "Conditional hardness for approximate coloring",
        "Combinatorial properties and the complexity of a max-cut approximation",
        "Laplacian eigenvalues and the maximum cut problem",
        "Derandomized dimensionality reduction with applications",
        "Improved Approximation Algorithms for MAX k-CUT and MAX BISECTION",
        "The Computational Structure of Monotone Monadic SNP and Constraint Satisfaction: A Study through Datalog and Group Theory",
        "The complexity of near-optimal graph coloring",
        "On the hardness of 4-coloring a 3-colorable graph",
        "Approximation algorithms and semidefinite programming",
        "Fooling Functions of Halfspaces under Product Distributions",
        "Improved inapproximability results for maximum k-colorable subgraph",
        "d-To-1 Hardness of Coloring 3-Colorable Graphs with O(1) Colors",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for maximum cut and satisfiability problems using semidefinite programming",
        "Tight bounds on the approximability of almost-satisfiable horn SAT and exact hitting set",
        "Some optimal inapproximability results",
        "NP-Hardness of Almost Coloring Almost 3-Colorable Graphs",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "On the power of unique 2-prover 1-round games",
        "Optimal Inapproximability Results for MAX-CUT and Other 2-Variable CSPs?",
        "The Complexity of General-Valued CSPs",
        "On the hardness of approximating the chromatic number",
        "Approximate graph coloring by semidefinite programming",
        "Pseudorandom sets in Grassmann graph have near-perfect expansion",
        "Algebraic properties of valued constraint satisfaction problem",
        "Topology and adjunction in promise constraint satisfaction",
        "Vertex cover might be hard to approximate to within 2−ε2𝜀2-\\varepsilon",
        "The approximability of constraint satisfaction problems",
        "Noise stability of functions with low influences: invariance and optimality",
        "Derandomizing approximation algorithms based on semidefinite programming",
        "Optimal algorithms and inapproximability results for every CSP?",
        "A multivariate Berry–Esseen theorem with explicit constants",
        "Algorithmic derandomization via complexity theory",
        "Gadgets, approximation, and linear programming",
        "The combined basic LP and affine IP relaxation for promise vcsps on infinite domains",
        "Bounds on the bivariate normal distribution function",
        "Finding almost-satisfying assignments"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Maximum 𝑘- vs. ℓ-colourings of graphsThis work was supported by UKRI EP/X024431/1 and by a Clarendon Fund Scholarship. For the purpose of Open Access, the authors have applied a CC BY public copyright licence to any Author Accepted Manuscript version arising from this submission. All data is provided in full in the results section of this paper., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
